[**2156-8-28**] 5:38 PM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 85815**]
 Reason: ? PNA
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  23 year old woman with craniectomy s/p TBI here with fever and cough
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  ? PNA
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 AP PORTABLE CHEST, [**2156-8-28**] AT 18:16 HOURS.

 HISTORY:  Craniectomy with history of traumatic brain injury with fever and
 cough.

 COMPARISON:  None.

 FINDINGS:  Please note, the technologist states that the patient could not
 follow breathing instructions for the examination.  Therefore, there is severe
 motion degradation of the exam rendering evaluation of the mid and lower lungs
 essentially nondiagnostic.  No gross complete opacification is noted, however
 further comment is reserved.  The mediastinum is grossly midline.  The cardiac
 silhouette is grossly within normal limits for size.  No large pneumothorax is
 seen.  There is tubing projecting to the right of midline into the abdomen
 from the neck, presumably ventriculoperitoneal shunt.  Additionally, there is
 an IVC filter present.

 IMPRESSION:  Nearly nondiagnostic study with no gross opacity noted.  If
 clinically feasible, consider repeat study.

 contrast was administered.

 ranging from [**2156-5-6**] to [**2156-8-28**].

 identified. Patient is status post left cranioplasty and placement of a
 right-sided parietal-approach VP shunt with tip position stable at the left
 foramen of [**Last Name (un) **].  Stable severe hydrocephalus and extensive unchanged white
 matter hypodensities bilaterally.  No shift of midline structures.
 Increased fluid in right sphenoid sinus.

 IMPRESSION:  Exam is unchanged with stable hydrocephalus and unchanged
 position of VP shunt.

notes.text:
Admission Date:  [**2156-8-28**]              Discharge Date:   [**2156-9-16**]

Date of Birth:  [**2133-2-14**]             Sex:   F

Service: NEUROLOGY

Allergies:
Amoxicillin

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 2569**]
Chief Complaint:
Fever

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None.


History of Present Illness:
Ms. [**Known lastname 28082**] is a previously healthy 23-year old woman who was hit
by a drunk driver in [**State 531**] and sustained massive traumatic
brain injuries in [**2155-12-29**], s/p craniectomy, cranioplasty,
and VP shunt, who currently presents from [**Hospital3 **] with
fever.  Per her parents, on [**2156-8-22**] she had a low grade
temperature of 100.0. On [**2156-8-25**]  she had two episodes of
nonbloody emesis, and she started to have a dry, nonproductive
cough. Ms. [**Known lastname 85111**] parents also noted that the she had
diaphoresis and increased movements. On [**2156-8-26**] they noticed
that her left eye, which has a keratograft and tarsorrhaphy,
became red and injected, with a small amount of purulent yellow
drainage. Per her parents, she has had eye infections multiple
times but they have resolved with drops. During the last week,
her rehab reports that she has been arching her back with head
turning to the left, has had increasing tone in LUE and lower
extremities, with flexion of the right arm. These episodes last
about 30 seconds and don't appear to be in repsonse to anything.
 For the past two weeks she has also had mottling on the lower
extremities, but this may be connected to their utilization of
the tilt table at rehab. At rehab on [**2156-8-28**], she had a
temperature of 101, and she may hvae had abdominal tenderness
per physician's exam (she grimaced with abdominal exam). She was
sent to the [**Hospital1 18**] ED and spiked to 102 while in triage at the
BED.
.
On arrival to the ED her initial VS were T99.4, HR 122, BP
122/71, RR 18, Sat 98%. On exam she was noted to have a
nontender abdomen, a maculopapular rash on her face (which her
parents said has been going on for weeks) and very cloudy urine.
Neurosurgery was consulted. Preliminary read of the CT scan of
her head (which was done with and without contrast at the
request of neurosurgery) did not show any clear focus of
infection in her head and was overall not significantly changed
from prior. Labs were notably primarily for a WBC of 11.9
(79%N), an LDH of 273 (no prior for comparison). Her UA was
relatively unremarkable and a CXR appeared to have no evidence
of a PNA although it was somewhat nondiagnostic.
.
Neurosurgery felt that she should be admitted to medicine for
workup of fever. They feel it is very unlikely that the cause of
her fever is her IC shunt given that she has had it for the
better part of a year, however if her workup remains negative
they could consider tapping it.
.
On the floor, she was tachycardic to 111, with a Tmax of 99.3
and BP of 133/69. She was nonverbal and therefore unable to give
history.
.
Review of systems:
(+) Per HPI
(-) Unable to assess. Parents confirm no diarrhea and no other
mental status changes. Other than HPI, she is at baseline.


Past Medical History:
1. L craniectomy and cranioplasty
2. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt
3. Traumatic Brain Injury
4. G-tube placement [**2156-1-29**]
5. Exposure keratopathy and keratitis of the L eye
6. s/p L tarsorrhaphy
7. Traumatic optic neuropathy of the left eye
8. Facial fractures, including Lefort III, b/l s/p open
reduction, internal fixation on [**2156-1-30**], type 2 nasal orbital
ethmoidal fractures.
9. L clavicle fracture s/p ORIF [**2156-2-4**]
10. Fracture of left coracoid process and inferior sternum
11. L medial malleolus fracture and left tibial plateau
fracture, s/p ORIF
12. Minimally displaced comminuted fracture of the L inferior
pubic rami and minimally displaced fracture of the superior
pubic ramus.
13. R transverse process fracture of L5
14. Vertical midling sacral fracture
15. Myositis ossificans of the R proximal quadriceps
16. B/L pulmonary contusions.
17. IVC filter placement [**2156-1-22**].
18. Hepatic laceration
19. Autonomic dysfunction
20. S/P L keratograft at Mass Eye & Ear in [**2-4**].

Social History:
Ms. [**Known lastname 28082**] was a previously healthy, fully functioning woman
prior to being hit by a drunk driver in [**Location (un) 7349**]. She is a graudate
of [**University/College 85112**] and was working as an aide for Mayor [**Last Name (un) 41364**]
prior to her accident. She is currently a resident at [**Hospital1 **]. She has a very supportive family and her parents are
quite involved in her care.


Family History:
non-contributory

Physical Exam:
Vitals: T: 99.3 BP: 133/69 P: 111 R: 20 O2: 98% on RA
General: In a vegetative state. Does not respond to voice,
sometimes withdraws from painful stimuli.
HEENT: Sclera anicteric, dried blood in oropharynx on tongue and
hard palate, along with a small amount of mcuous on tongue.
Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales,
ronchi
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs,
gallops
Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present,
no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly, large
ecchymoses on lower quadrants b/l, PEG tube site looks clean,
dry, and intact, w/o erythema
GU: Foley
Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ DP pulses b/l, mottled pattern
resembling livedo reticularis on both lower extremities.
Skin: no rashes or ulcers
Neuro: in a vegetative state, nonresponsive, nonverbal. R pupil
with sluggish response to light; unable to assess L pupil as not
visible due to opacity over left [**Doctor First Name 2281**] and pupil. Roving eye
movements horizontally. L arm flexed, with decortical
spontaneous movements of all extremities. Unable to elicit
reflexes in upper extremities, but right patellar reflex 2+, and
2-3 beats of clonus in Right foot.


Pertinent Results:
[**2156-8-28**] 04:05PM   WBC-11.9* RBC-3.90* HGB-12.7 HCT-36.2 MCV-93
MCH-32.7* MCHC-35.2* RDW-14.3
[**2156-8-28**] 04:05PM   NEUTS-78.9* LYMPHS-11.8* MONOS-7.1 EOS-1.4
BASOS-0.8
[**2156-8-28**] 04:05PM   GLUCOSE-114* LACTATE-1.2 NA+-138 K+-4.0
CL--101 TCO2-28
[**2156-8-28**] 04:05PM   ALT(SGPT)-22 AST(SGOT)-21 LD(LDH)-273* ALK
PHOS-80 TOT BILI-0.5
[**2156-8-28**] 04:40PM URINE  RBC-0-2 WBC-0-2 BACTERIA-OCC YEAST-NONE
EPI-[**1-30**]
[**2156-8-28**] 04:40PM URINE  BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-TR
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-8.0
LEUK-NEG
[**2156-8-28**] 04:40PM URINE  COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Hazy SP [**Last Name (un) 155**]-1.011

Imaging:
[**2156-8-28**] CXR:Nearly nondiagnostic study with no gross opacity
noted. If clinically feasible, consider repeat study.  IVC
filter present. VP shunt visible.
.
[**2156-8-29**] CT head with and w/o contrast:
1. No significant interval change. Persistent stable
ventriculomegaly and hydrocephalus.
2. No interval change in position of the VP shunt.
3. No definite rim-enhancing fluid collection. Post-contrast
images degraded by motion
.
[**2156-8-29**] CXR: Prelim read: no pleural effusion, evidence of
pneumonia, no retrocardiac effusion, no pulmonary edema, no lung
nodules or masses, minimal retrocardiac effusion, normal cardiac
silhoutte. VP shunt visible.
.
[**2156-8-29**] CT Abdomen/Pelvis with and w/o contrast:
Normal intraperitoneal course of VP shunt with no kinking or
fracture
identified. Normal appearing adjacent fluid.
Trace of free fluid noted in both adnexae. The uterus and both
adnexa are normal with simple follicular cyst identified in
relation to both ovaries. No adenopathy.  The rectum and sigmoid
colon are unremarkable.
Urinary catheter noted within the bladder.




Brief Hospital Course:
[**Known lastname 28082**] was admitted to the medicine service for fever of unknown
source. She is in a persistent vegetative state at baseline. A
full workup for fever remained negative. She was found on
[**2156-8-31**] to have a generalized seizure. Her oxygen saturation was
in the 80's at that moment and she was intubated and transferred
to the ICU. In the ICU she was placed on two AED's (dilantin and
Keppra). Her Shunt was tapped and adjusted per neurosurgery. One
of two bottles from the CSF grew out coagulase negative staph.
We believe this is a contaminate given the benign nature of the
CSF profile. Still she was started on empiric antibiotics which
were Vancomycin and Ceftazidime. This was written for a 7 day
course and completed. She was subsequently afebrile. She was
extubated on [**2156-9-2**] and observed in the ICU overnight. There
were no acute events. She was transferred to the floor for
further care.

On the floor her antiepileptic drugs were adjusted to ensure
control with oral agents. Dilantin was stopped and valproate
started. Keppra was continued. Tube feeds were increased with
two three hour pauses daily to give these medications (hold one
hour before and two hours after). She had no further seizures on
the floor. Occulopalatal myoclonus continued.

Medications on Admission:
MED Sodium Chloride 0.9% Flush 3 mL IV Q8H:PRN line flush
Peripheral line: Flush with 3 mL Normal Saline every 8 hours and
PRN.
MED Acetaminophen 1000 mg NG Q6H:PRN fever
Do not exceed 4gm per day.

please schedule for 0700, 1200

please give through G tube

please schedule for 0800, 1400

Discharge Medications:

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the [**Hospital1 69**] on
[**2149-8-28**] because at your rehabilatation facility, [**Hospital1 **], you
had a temperature up to 101. We performed multiple tests to
determine the cause of your fever, but your work up was
negative. You were found to have seizures. You were intubated
for a short period of time while your seizures were better
controlled. We started you on two medications for this (Keppra
and Dilantin). You were placed on antibiotics without a definite
source of infection, later discontinued. Dilantin was stopped
and replaced by valproic acid. You were discharged seziure-free
on oral keppra and valproate.

Followup Instructions:

with your physicians there.

 CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST                                            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 85982**]
 Reason: evaluate hydrocephalus
 Admitting Diagnosis: FEVER
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  23 year old woman with TBI, s/p VPS, p/w seizures, eyes downward deviation
  concerning for increased hydrocephalus
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  evaluate hydrocephalus
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) 10889**] [**Doctor First Name 141**] [**2156-9-9**] 6:55 PM
  No significant interval change with stable severe hydrocephalus status post VP
  shunt placement, unchanged in position.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  23-year-old female status post TBI and VP shunt who presents with
 seizures and downward deviation of eyes concerning for increasing
 hydrocephalus.

 COMPARISON:  [**2156-9-2**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images through the brain were obtained.

 FINDINGS:  Evaluation of the current study in comparison to the prior is
 somewhat limited secondary to rotation of the patient in the scanner on both
 studies.  With this limitation in mind, there is no significant interval
 change.  Again noted is stable marked hydrocephalus with stable-appearing
 periventricular hypodensities, possibly related to transependymal migration of
 CSF and/or encephalomalacia.  A right parietal VP shunt catheter is again
 noted terminating in the left foramen of [**Doctor Last Name 8408**], unchanged in position.  The
 patient is status post left craniectomy, also unchanged in appearance.  There
 has been no interval intraparenchymal hemorrhage, large acute territorial
 infarction, or shift of midline structures. The patient is status post
 fixation of numerous remote facial fractures, unchanged from the prior study.
 No new fractures are identified.  The mastoid air cells are normally aerated.

 IMPRESSION:

 No significant interval change with stable severe hydrocephalus status post VP
 shunt placement, unchanged in position.

 INDICATION:  A 23-year-old female with seizures and contractures, rule out
 DVT.

 COMPARISON:  No previous exam for comparison.

 FINDINGS:  Grayscale, color and Doppler images were obtained of bilateral
 common femoral, superficial femoral, popliteal and tibial veins.  Note is made
 that a vascular line is in place in the right groin.  There is normal flow,
 compression and augmentation seen in all of the vessels.

 IMPRESSION:  No evidence of deep vein thrombosis in either leg.

                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  TBI with ventilation.

 FINDINGS:  In comparison with the study of [**9-2**], the endotracheal tube has
 been removed.  There is a somewhat ill-defined area of patchy opacification at
 the right base.  Although this could represent merely atelectasis, in the
 appropriate clinical setting, the possibility of pneumonia must be seriously
 considered.  The basilar atelectasis on the left is decreasing.  Of incidental
 note is the metallic device about previous left clavicle fracture.

 IMPRESSION:  Possible developing consolidation at the right base.

[**2156-9-2**] 10:37 AM
 CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST                                            Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 86622**]
 Reason: 23 y/o with TBI, Crani, shunt,New seizures. Underwent shunt
 Admitting Diagnosis: FEVER
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  23 y/o with TBI, Crani, shunt,New seizures. Underwent shunt adjustment.
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  23 y/o with TBI, Crani, shunt,New seizures. Underwent shunt adjustment.
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 WET READ: IPf [**Doctor First Name 141**] [**2156-9-2**] 11:09 AM
  No interval change.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  23-year-old with TBI, craniotomy, and shunt with new seizures.
 Underwent shunt adjustment.

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images were obtained through the brain.  No
 intravenous contrast was administered.

 COMPARISON:  Multiple prior CTs, last one done [**2156-9-1**].

 FINDINGS:  Scan is slightly suboptimal due to patient rotation in the scanner.
 With this limitation in mind, there is no significant interval change.  There
 is no evidence of acute hemorrhage, large acute territorial infarction, or
 large masses.  The patient is status post remote left cranioplasty. There is a
 right-sided parietal post-VP shunt with its tip positioned stable at the left
 foramen of [**Last Name (un) **].

 There is a stable severe hydrocephalus, with bilateral periventricular
 hypodensities, which could be combination of encephalomalacia, or
 transependymal migration of cerebrospinal fluid.  There is no shift of midline
 structures.  There is fluid in the sphenoid sinus, (2:9), which appears
 similar compared to prior.

 IMPRESSION:  No significant interval change.  Stable severe hydrocephalus with
 similar position of VP shunt.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 TYPE OF EXAMINATION:  Chest AP portable single view.

 INDICATION:  23-year-old female patient with status epilepticus, now status
 post intubation, evaluate position of ETT.

 FINDINGS:  AP single view of the chest has been obtained with patient in
 sitting semi-upright position.  Comparison is made with the next preceding
 similar study of [**2156-8-29**].  During the interval, the patient has been
 intubated, the ETT seen to terminate in the trachea some 4 cm above the level
 of the carina.  No pneumothorax is present.  As before, evidence of hardware
 for left clavicular fixation and ventriculoperitoneal shunt line overlying
 mediastinum on frontal view examination.  Thus, stable chest findings.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of ETT, no pneumothorax or any other
 placement-related complication.

notes.text:
[**2156-8-28**] 6:14 PM
 CT HEAD W/ & W/O CONTRAST                                       Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 86541**]
 Reason: TBI CRANIECTOMY AND CRANIOPLASTY NOW WITH FEVER, ? IC SOURCE OF INFECTION
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 90
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  23 year old woman with TBI craniectomy and cranioplasty now w/fever
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  ? IC source of infection
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 WET READ: IPf SAT [**2156-8-28**] 6:41 PM
  No significant interval change with massive hydrocephalus. VP shunt appears
  unchanged.
  No rim enhancing fluid collection.
  More fluid in the sphenoid sinus.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  23-year-old woman with craniectomy and cranioplasty, presents with
 fever.

 TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images were obtained through the brain pre- and
 post-IV contrast administration.

 COMPARISON:  Multiple prior CT, last one [**2156-8-9**].

 FINDINGS:  There is no significant interval change.  The patient is status
 post left cranioplasty.

 There is stable massive hydrocephalus with periventricular hypodensities in
 the white matter, suggesting transependymal reabsorption of CSF.

 VP shunt appears unchanged in position compared to prior study.  There is no
 shift of midline structures.  On post-contrast images, there is no gross
 rim-enhancing fluid collection.  Images however are degraded by motion.  There
 is fluid within the sphenoid sinus.  There is evidence of prior surgery at the
 anterior wall of the left maxillary sinus.  The globes are intact.

 IMPRESSION:

 1.  No significant interval change.  Persistent stable ventriculomegaly and
 hydrocephalus.

 2.  No interval change in position of the VP shunt.

 3.  No definite rim-enhancing fluid collection. Post-contrast images degraded
 by motion.

 Please note that CT head with IV contrast has limited sensitivty for
 infection.  Consider correaltion with CSF fluid analysis.  If more imaging is
 indicated, MRI is more sensitive.
                                                             (Over)

notes.text:
[**2156-8-29**] 5:14 PM
 CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST                     Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 86542**]
 Reason: FEVERS, EXAMINE VP SHUNT DISTAL REGION
 Admitting Diagnosis: FEVER
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  23 year old woman with traumatic brain injury, now presenting with fevers
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  please examine VP shunt distal region
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS

 INDICATION:  23-year-old female with traumatic brain injury.  Presents with
 fever.  ? VP shunt.

 COMPARISON:  No prior CT abdomen available for comparison.

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axially acquired images from the lung bases to the pubic
 symphysis, displayed with 5-mm slice thickness with oral and IV contrast.
 Coronal and sagittal reformats have been provided.

 FINDINGS:

 CT ABDOMEN:

 Imaged lung bases are clear.
 No pneumoperitoneum.
 Liver, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands, and kidneys are
 unremarkable.
 No retroperitoneal masses or adenopathy.
 No abnormally dilated or thickened or dilated small or large bowel loops.
 IVC filter noted in situ.
 The VP shunt can be traced throughout the peritoneal cavity with no evidence
 of kinking or fracture identified.
 The tip terminates in the left flank adjacent to the descending colon (series
 2, image 74).
 No surrounding inflammatory change or collection identified.


 CT PELVIS:
 Trace of free fluid noted in both adnexae.
 The uterus and both adnexa are normal with simple follicular cyst identified
 in relation to both ovaries.  No  adenopathy.
 The rectum and sigmoid colon are unremarkable.
 Urinary catheter noted within the bladder.

 CT OSSEOUS SKELETON:  No osseous destructive lesion.  There is heterotopic new
 bone formation in relation to the right sartorius and adductor muscle group
 within the thigh (series 2, image 93).

                                                             (Over)

 [**2156-8-29**] 5:14 PM
 CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST                     Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 86542**]
 Reason: FEVERS, EXAMINE VP SHUNT DISTAL REGION
 Admitting Diagnosis: FEVER
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 IMPRESSION:
 Normal intraperitoneal course of VP shunt with no kinking or fracture
 identified.  Normal appearing adjacent fluid.
